title: SEO and Meta
description: Improve your Nuxt app's SEO with powerful head config, composables and components.

children.value: Improve your Nuxt app's SEO with powerful head config, composables and components.
allows you to customize the head for your entire app.
This method does not allow you to provide reactive data, if you need global reactive data you can use
Shortcuts are available to make configuration easier:
. You can also provide any of the keys listed below in
Out-of-the-box, Nuxt provides sane defaults, which you can override if needed.
composable function allows you to manage your head tags in a programmatic and reactive way, powered by
As with all composables, it can only be used with a components

props.code:
<script setup lang="ts">
useHead({
  title: 'My App',
  meta: [
    { name: 'description', content: 'My amazing site.' }
  ],
  bodyAttrs: {
    class: 'test'
  },
  script: [ { children: 'console.log(\'Hello world\')' } ]
})
</script>

children.value: composables let you define your site's SEO meta tags as a flat object with full TypeScript support.
This helps you avoid typos and common mistakes, such as using
In most instances, the meta does not need to be reactive as robots will only scan the initial load. So we recommend using
as a performance-focused utility that will not do anything (or return a

props.code:
<script setup lang="ts">
useServerSeoMeta({
  title: 'My Amazing Site',
  ogTitle: 'My Amazing Site',
  description: 'This is my amazing site, let me tell you all about it.',
  ogDescription: 'This is my amazing site, let me tell you all about it.',
  ogImage: 'https://example.com/image.png',
  twitterCard: 'summary_large_image',
})
</script>

children.value: 'This is my amazing site, let me tell you all about it.'
'This is my amazing site, let me tell you all about it.'

When inserting tags that are reactive, for example, from an API request, you should
use the computed getter syntax, the same as

props.code:
<script setup lang="ts">
const data = useFetch(() => $fetch('/api/example'))

useServerSeoMeta({
  ogTitle: () => `${data.value?.title} - My Site`,
  description: () => data.value?.description,
  ogDescription: () => data.value?.description,
})
</script>

children.value: components so that you can interact directly with your metadata within your component's template.
Because these component names match native HTML elements, it is very important that they are capitalized in the template.
can accept nested meta tags (for aesthetic reasons) but this has no effect on
the nested meta tags are rendered in the final HTML.
The below is the non-reactive types used for
Reactivity is supported on all properties, as computed, computed getter refs and reactive.
It's recommended to use computed getters (

props.code:
<script setup lang="ts">
const desc = ref('My amazing site.')

useHead({
  meta: [
    { name: 'description', content: desc }
  ],
})
</script>

children.value: option to provide a dynamic template for customizing the title of your site. for example, by adding the name of your site to the title of every page.
can either be a string, where
is replaced with the title, or a function.
If you want to use a function (for full control), then this cannot be set in your
, and it is recommended instead to set it within your
file, where it will apply to all pages on your site:

props.code:
<script setup lang="ts">
useHead({
  titleTemplate: (titleChunk) => {
    return titleChunk ? `${titleChunk} - Site Title` : 'Site Title';
  }
})
</script>

children.value: Now, if you set the title to
on another page of your site, the title would appear as 'My Page - Site Title' in the browser tab. You could also pass
to default to the site title.
meta tags to append them to the end of the

props.code:
<script setup lang="ts">
useHead({
  script: [
    {
      src: 'https://third-party-script.com',
      body: true
    }
  ]
})
</script>

children.value: to set metadata based on the current route.
For example, you can first set the current page title (this is extracted at build time via a macro, so it can't be set dynamically):
And then in your layout file, you might use the route's metadata you have previously set:

props.code:
<script setup>
const route = useRoute()

useHead({
  meta: [{ property: 'og:title', content: `App Name - ${route.meta.title}` }]
})
</script>

children.value: is set either as a string with the
, which allows greater flexibility in setting the page title dynamically for each route of your Nuxt app:

props.code:
<script setup>
useHead({
  // as a string,
  // where `%s` is replaced with the title
  titleTemplate: '%s - Site Title',
  // ... or as a function
  titleTemplate: (productCategory) => {
    return productCategory
      ? `${productCategory} - Site Title`
      : 'Site Title'
  }
})
</script>

children.value: // where `%s` is replaced with the title
is also used as an alternative way of setting the page title. However,
does not allow the page title to be dynamic. Therefore, it is recommended to use
file to add a dynamic title, which is then applied to all routes of your Nuxt app.
The example below shows how you might enable Google Fonts using either the

props.code:
<script setup lang="ts">
useHead({
  link: [
    {
      rel: 'preconnect',
      href: 'https://fonts.googleapis.com'
    },
    {
      rel: 'stylesheet',
      href: 'https://fonts.googleapis.com/css2?family=Roboto&display=swap',
      crossorigin: ''
    }
  ]
})
</script>
